Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

Back at work after three weeks off, and guess what? No return-to-work scaries here, because my team (the absolute legends) did too good of a job in my absence. I came back to a mostly empty workload. Huuuuge shoutout to the gals 👏LOVE👏YOUR👏WORK👏!Thankfully, a job briefing and a freshly written job ad snapped me out of my work drought (my personal hell), reminding me just how much I love what I do.If this doesn’t sound like you—if your job isn’t giving you that spark—maybe we should talk. If we don't have the perfect role right now? No worries. The right one might be just around the corner.Slide into my inbox. As a foreign journalist living in the U.S., I’ve noticed that breaking into American newsrooms is incredibly challenging. Many news organizations seem hesitant to hire non-citizen reporters, even when they have the necessary work authorizat ion and relevant experience with bachelor's/master's degree in Journalism & Mass Communication.Why do American news channels rarely offer opportunities to foreign journalists living in the U.S.? Is it due to work visa complexities, industry preferences, or something else?I’d love to hear insights from fellow journalists, hiring managers, and media professionals. Have you faced similar challenges, or do you know of organizations that value international perspectives in their newsrooms? Let’s discuss! 👇hashtag#Journalism hashtag#MediaJobs hashtag#ForeignJournalists hashtag#DiversityInNews hashtag#Hiring hashtag#CareerAdvice Skynewsuk.com CNN PBS News PBS BBC News Taylor Petras International Journalists'​ Network (IJNet)

I’m hashtag#hiring for a backend engineer for my team, please ping me if interested thank you! hashtag#java hashtag#aws

Hiring should be efficient. So why is finding top talent taking so long?Sifting through resumes, conducting multiple interviews, and still struggling to find the right fit? We get it. That’s why we’ve streamlined our vetting process to help companies connect with top 5% vetted remote developers, designers, and product managers, fast and efficiently.Here’s how we do it:✅ Profile Screening – We review skills, training, and industry experience to filter the best candidates. ✅ Communication Assessment – We verify English fluency and remote readiness through live interviews or video self-introductions. ✅ Technical Interview – A one-hour expert interview or pair programming session ensures top-level problem-solving skills. ✅ Final Review – We continuously assess performance to maintain high-quality standards.No more wasted time. Just top-tier, vetted professionals ready to help you scale.hashtag#SecondTalent hashtag#hiring hashtag#remotework hashtag#techtalent hashtag#vettingprocess hashtag#efficienthiring

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

Hiring should be efficient. So why is finding top talent taking so long?Sifting through resumes, conducting multiple interviews, and still struggling to find the right fit? We get it. That’s why we’ve streamlined our vetting process to help companies connect with top 5% vetted remote developers, designers, and product managers, fast and efficiently.Here’s how we do it:✅ Profile Screening – We review skills, training, and industry experience to filter the best candidates. ✅ Communication Assessment – We verify English fluency and remote readiness through live interviews or video self-introductions. ✅ Technical Interview – A one-hour expert interview or pair programming session ensures top-level problem-solving skills. ✅ Final Review – We continuously assess performance to maintain high-quality standards.No more wasted time. When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.



…more

Why Recruiters Don't Call Back.Ever sent your resume into the recruitment void, only to hear...nothing? That silence isn't just frustrating - it's mystifying.Here's the inside story.1. We forgetPicture this: A recruiter scanning hundreds of profiles, juggling phone calls with candidates, updating clients, rushing to meetings, and trying to document everything at once. Some days, our follow-up messages get buried under an avalanche of tasks. Not an excuse, but the honest reality of our chaotic days.2. We have no news"Any news on my application?" you ask. Sometimes we wonder the same thing! Many clients go silent for weeks, leaving us empty-handed when you reach out. We wish we had updates to share.3. We can't fit you at the momentIf you're not a fit for current roles, you join our "future talent" database. We work to fill specific client needs - they're the ones paying our bills. But when something perfect crosses our desk? You'll be our first call.4. We can't figure you outThose unexplained gaps in your resume? The 5 jobs in 3 years? That vague description of what you actually do? These things make us hesitate. Part of our job is spotting potential red flags before our clients do.5. We struggle with uncomfortable truthsSometimes, the feedback is awkward to deliver. A client might pass on you because of something said in an informal reference check or how you presented yourself (read: personal appearance). These conversations are difficult to navigate without someone getting hurt.We genuinely feel bad when communications drop. You deserve better, and the good recruiters know it.What's been your experience with recruitment communication? Has silence left you questioning your candidacy?hashtag#recruitment hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#positivelinksasia

Traditional recruitment often heavily emphasises past job titles, years of experience, and specific skills listed on resumes. I've noticed that focusing too much on the past can sometimes limit our view of a candidate's true potential. After all, we are recruiting for the future! ➡️ I believe that a growth mindset, a positive attitude, and a passion for learning are just as valuable. While some roles do have very specific requirements and previous experience is necessary, other roles can and should be more open to non-traditional backgrounds with transferable skills.Although, Gemini's picture suggestion for this post highlights that sometimes past experience is extremely crucial. For example, I wouldn’t go rock climbing with just a harness and no rope! 😂 I hope she has a can-do attitude..Happy Friday!

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.

Why Recruiters Don't Call Back.Ever sent your resume into the recruitment void, only to hear...nothing? That silence isn't just frustrating - it's mystifying.Here's the inside story.1. We forgetPicture this: A recruiter scanning hundreds of profiles, juggling phone calls with candidates, updating clients, rushing to meetings, and trying to document everything at once. Some days, our follow-up messages get buried under an avalanche of tasks. Not an excuse, but the honest reality of our chaotic days.2. We have no news"Any news on my application?" you ask. Sometimes we wonder the same thing! Many clients go silent for weeks, leaving us empty-handed when you reach out. We wish we had updates to share.3. We can't fit you at the momentIf you're not a fit for current roles, you join our "future talent" database. We work to fill specific client needs - they're the ones paying our bills. But when something perfect crosses our desk? You'll be our first call.4. We can't figure you outThose unexplained gaps in your resume? The 5 jobs in 3 years? That vague description of what you actually do? These things make us hesitate. Part of our job is spotting potential red flags before our clients do.5. We struggle with uncomfortable truthsSometimes, the feedback is awkward to deliver. A client might pass on you because of something said in an informal reference check or how you presented yourself (read: personal appearance). These conversations are difficult to navigate without someone getting hurt.We genuinely feel bad when communications drop. You deserve better, and the good recruiters know it.What's been your experience with recruitment communication? Has silence left you questioning your candidacy?hashtag#recruitment hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#positivelinksasia

Traditional recruitment often heavily emphasises past job titles, years of experience, and specific skills listed on resumes. I've noticed that focusing too much on the past can sometimes limit our view of a candidate's true potential. After all, we are recruiting for the future! ➡️ I believe that a growth mindset, a positive attitude, and a passion for learning are just as valuable. While some roles do have very specific requirements and previous experience is necessary, other roles can and should be more open to non-traditional backgrounds with transferable skills.Although, Gemini's picture suggestion for this post highlights that sometimes past experience is extremely crucial. For example, I wouldn’t go rock climbing with just a harness and no rope! 😂 I hope she has a can-do attitude..Happy Friday!

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

Hiring should be efficient. So why is finding top talent taking so long?Sifting through resumes, conducting multiple interviews, and still struggling to find the right fit? We get it. That’s why we’ve streamlined our vetting process to help companies connect with top 5% vetted remote developers, designers, and product managers, fast and efficiently.Here’s how we do it:✅ Profile Screening – We review skills, training, and industry experience to filter the best candidates. ✅ Communication Assessment – We verify English fluency and remote readiness through live interviews or video self-introductions. ✅ Technical Interview – A one-hour expert interview or pair programming session ensures top-level problem-solving skills. ✅ Final Review – We continuously assess performance to maintain high-quality standards.No more wasted time. Just top-tier, vetted professionals ready to help you scale.hashtag#SecondTalent hashtag#hiring hashtag#remotework hashtag#techtalent hashtag#vettingprocess hashtag#efficienthiring

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.



…more

Why Recruiters Don't Call Back.Ever sent your resume into the recruitment void, only to hear...nothing? That silence isn't just frustrating - it's mystifying.Here's the inside story.1. We forgetPicture this: A recruiter scanning hundreds of profiles, juggling phone calls with candidates, updating clients, rushing to meetings, and trying to document everything at once. Some days, our follow-up messages get buried under an avalanche of tasks. Not an excuse, but the honest reality of our chaotic days.2. We have no news"Any news on my application?" you ask. Sometimes we wonder the same thing! Many clients go silent for weeks, leaving us empty-handed when you reach out. We wish we had updates to share.3. We can't fit you at the momentIf you're not a fit for current roles, you join our "future talent" database. We work to fill specific client needs - they're the ones paying our bills. But when something perfect crosses our desk? You'll be our first call.4. We can't figure you outThose unexplained gaps in your resume? The 5 jobs in 3 years? That vague description of what you actually do? These things make us hesitate. Part of our job is spotting potential red flags before our clients do.5. We struggle with uncomfortable truthsSometimes, the feedback is awkward to deliver. A client might pass on you because of something said in an informal reference check or how you presented yourself (read: personal appearance). These conversations are difficult to navigate without someone getting hurt.We genuinely feel bad when communications drop. You deserve better, and the good recruiters know it.What's been your experience with recruitment communication? Has silence left you questioning your candidacy?hashtag#recruitment hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#positivelinksasia

Traditional recruitment often heavily emphasises past job titles, years of experience, and specific skills listed on resumes. I've noticed that focusing too much on the past can sometimes limit our view of a candidate's true potential. After all, we are recruiting for the future! ➡️ I believe that a growth mindset, a positive attitude, and a passion for learning are just as valuable. While some roles do have very specific requirements and previous experience is necessary, other roles can and should be more open to non-traditional backgrounds with transferable skills.Although, Gemini's picture suggestion for this post highlights that sometimes past experience is extremely crucial. For example, I wouldn’t go rock climbing with just a harness and no rope! 😂 I hope she has a can-do attitude..Happy Friday!

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

Hiring should be efficient. So why is finding top talent taking so long?Sifting through resumes, conducting multiple interviews, and still struggling to find the right fit? We get it. That’s why we’ve streamlined our vetting process to help companies connect with top 5% vetted remote developers, designers, and product managers, fast and efficiently.Here’s how we do it:✅ Profile Screening – We review skills, training, and industry experience to filter the best candidates. ✅ Communication Assessment – We verify English fluency and remote readiness through live interviews or video self-introductions. ✅ Technical Interview – A one-hour expert interview or pair programming session ensures top-level problem-solving skills. ✅ Final Review – We continuously assess performance to maintain high-quality standards.No more wasted time. When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.



…more

Why Recruiters Don't Call Back.Ever sent your resume into the recruitment void, only to hear...nothing? That silence isn't just frustrating - it's mystifying.Here's the inside story.1. We forgetPicture this: A recruiter scanning hundreds of profiles, juggling phone calls with candidates, updating clients, rushing to meetings, and trying to document everything at once. Some days, our follow-up messages get buried under an avalanche of tasks. Not an excuse, but the honest reality of our chaotic days.2. We have no news"Any news on my application?" you ask. Sometimes we wonder the same thing! Many clients go silent for weeks, leaving us empty-handed when you reach out. We wish we had updates to share.3. We can't fit you at the momentIf you're not a fit for current roles, you join our "future talent" database. We work to fill specific client needs - they're the ones paying our bills. But when something perfect crosses our desk? You'll be our first call.4. We can't figure you outThose unexplained gaps in your resume? The 5 jobs in 3 years? That vague description of what you actually do? These things make us hesitate. Part of our job is spotting potential red flags before our clients do.5. We struggle with uncomfortable truthsSometimes, the feedback is awkward to deliver. A client might pass on you because of something said in an informal reference check or how you presented yourself (read: personal appearance). These conversations are difficult to navigate without someone getting hurt.We genuinely feel bad when communications drop. You deserve better, and the good recruiters know it.What's been your experience with recruitment communication? Has silence left you questioning your candidacy?hashtag#recruitment hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#positivelinksasia

Traditional recruitment often heavily emphasises past job titles, years of experience, and specific skills listed on resumes. I've noticed that focusing too much on the past can sometimes limit our view of a candidate's true potential. After all, we are recruiting for the future! ➡️ I believe that a growth mindset, a positive attitude, and a passion for learning are just as valuable. While some roles do have very specific requirements and previous experience is necessary, other roles can and should be more open to non-traditional backgrounds with transferable skills.Although, Gemini's picture suggestion for this post highlights that sometimes past experience is extremely crucial. For example, I wouldn’t go rock climbing with just a harness and no rope! 😂 I hope she has a can-do attitude..Happy Friday!

hashtag#hiring *Sr. Software Engineer - 10% 401k - FS Poly with Security Clearance*, Chantilly, *United States*, fulltime hashtag#opentowork hashtag#Chantillyjobs hashtag#Virginiajobs hashtag#ITCommunications*To Apply -->*: https://lnkd.in/difSfRjV In a space where it is hard to be unique, our client is a VERY DIFFERENT COMPANY. The founders, former Intelligence Community technology executives, have built the kind of company they always wanted to be part of. The most unusual aspect is that people move freely from project to project - in addition to their 20+ vehicles for DIA and CIA work and their commercial customers, the CEO often can literally pick up the phone, call the customer, and get added to new work that interests an employee. The work itself is also amazing and as close to the mission as you will find - Data Science and Analytics work, counterterrorism, counterproliferation, targeting, virtual operations, exploits, HUMINT research, and other missions. They prime on several programs and also have a number of subcontracts, and they always need engineers with a TS/SCI + FS Poly in Reston, Chantilly, McLean, and other sites in Virginia. Salaries here are quite good, plus a 10% 401(k) contribution, 7 weeks of PTO, and excellent health/medical/dental coverage. It's a unique combination of great work, great people, and great compensation - low bureaucracy, technology agnostic, massively mission-focused, and extremely well-funded. They are seeking a Sr. Software Engineer to join their team. Relevant qualifications: -Bachelor's Degree in Computer Science or similar -8+ years of professional experience -Experience with Java, JavaScript, and Python -Experience with Elasticsearch, Kubernetes, NiFi, and RabbitMQ -Experience with building and deploying cloud infrastructure (CloudFormation, Ansible, Puppet) -Experience building APIs (REST, Hadoop, Spark) or automation (Jenkins, Maven) or monitoring technologies (ELK, Grafana, Prometheus) This role is located in Chantilly, VA and requires a TS/SCI + FS Polygraph.

Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.



…more

Why Recruiters Don't Call Back.Ever sent your resume into the recruitment void, only to hear...nothing? That silence isn't just frustrating - it's mystifying.Here's the inside story.1. We forgetPicture this: A recruiter scanning hundreds of profiles, juggling phone calls with candidates, updating clients, rushing to meetings, and trying to document everything at once. Some days, our follow-up messages get buried under an avalanche of tasks. Not an excuse, but the honest reality of our chaotic days.2. We have no news"Any news on my application?" you ask. Sometimes we wonder the same thing! Many clients go silent for weeks, leaving us empty-handed when you reach out. We wish we had updates to share.3. We can't fit you at the momentIf you're not a fit for current roles, you join our "future talent" database. We work to fill specific client needs - they're the ones paying our bills. But when something perfect crosses our desk? You'll be our first call.4. We can't figure you outThose unexplained gaps in your resume? The 5 jobs in 3 years? That vague description of what you actually do? These things make us hesitate. Part of our job is spotting potential red flags before our clients do.5. We struggle with uncomfortable truthsSometimes, the feedback is awkward to deliver. A client might pass on you because of something said in an informal reference check or how you presented yourself (read: personal appearance). These conversations are difficult to navigate without someone getting hurt.We genuinely feel bad when communications drop. You deserve better, and the good recruiters know it.What's been your experience with recruitment communication? Has silence left you questioning your candidacy?hashtag#recruitment hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#positivelinksasia

Traditional recruitment often heavily emphasises past job titles, years of experience, and specific skills listed on resumes. I've noticed that focusing too much on the past can sometimes limit our view of a candidate's true potential. After all, we are recruiting for the future! ➡️ I believe that a growth mindset, a positive attitude, and a passion for learning are just as valuable. While some roles do have very specific requirements and previous experience is necessary, other roles can and should be more open to non-traditional backgrounds with transferable skills.Although, Gemini's picture suggestion for this post highlights that sometimes past experience is extremely crucial. For example, I wouldn’t go rock climbing with just a harness and no rope! 😂 I hope she has a can-do attitude..Happy Friday!

hashtag#hiring *Sr. Software Engineer - 10% 401k - FS Poly with Security Clearance*, Chantilly, *United States*, fulltime hashtag#opentowork hashtag#Chantillyjobs hashtag#Virginiajobs hashtag#ITCommunications*To Apply -->*: https://lnkd.in/difSfRjV In a space where it is hard to be unique, our client is a VERY DIFFERENT COMPANY. The founders, former Intelligence Community technology executives, have built the kind of company they always wanted to be part of. The most unusual aspect is that people move freely from project to project - in addition to their 20+ vehicles for DIA and CIA work and their commercial customers, the CEO often can literally pick up the phone, call the customer, and get added to new work that interests an employee. The work itself is also amazing and as close to the mission as you will find - Data Science and Analytics work, counterterrorism, counterproliferation, targeting, virtual operations, exploits, HUMINT research, and other missions. They prime on several programs and also have a number of subcontracts, and they always need engineers with a TS/SCI + FS Poly in Reston, Chantilly, McLean, and other sites in Virginia. Salaries here are quite good, plus a 10% 401(k) contribution, 7 weeks of PTO, and excellent health/medical/dental coverage. It's a unique combination of great work, great people, and great compensation - low bureaucracy, technology agnostic, massively mission-focused, and extremely well-funded. They are seeking a Sr. Software Engineer to join their team. Relevant qualifications: -Bachelor's Degree in Computer Science or similar -8+ years of professional experience -Experience with Java, JavaScript, and Python -Experience with Elasticsearch, Kubernetes, NiFi, and RabbitMQ -Experience with building and deploying cloud infrastructure (CloudFormation, Ansible, Puppet) -Experience building APIs (REST, Hadoop, Spark) or automation (Jenkins, Maven) or monitoring technologies (ELK, Grafana, Prometheus) This role is located in Chantilly, VA and requires a TS/SCI + FS Polygraph.

Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips

How Java Works: A Step-by-Step Breakdown with Examples 1. Setup 🛠️ • Hardware: Your computer • OS: The platform running your code • JDK: Java Development Kit - your essential toolbox2. Write Code 💡 Example: ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ```3. Compilation  • Javac compiler translates Java code to bytecode4. Transformation  • Result: .class file (bytecode)5. Execution  • JVM (Java Virtual Machine) reads bytecode • JIT compiler optimizes performance • JRE (Java Runtime Environment) runs the code • Execution begins at main() method6. Output  • Your computer displays: "Hello, World!"Have I overlooked anything? Follow Rajkumar ChintalapudiPlease share your thoughts—your insights are priceless to me.

HORROR STORY!....Just got off the phone with a skilled professional I’ve known for years. We’ve kept in touch regularly - I’ve offered him market insights, job search support, and a genuine interest in his career.During our chat, he told me about another candidate currently looking for work, and let me tell you… he’s had a week from hell.He was working with a recruiter who sent him to a meeting with a client…Only to arrive and be told: “We weren’t expecting you... and that role’s already been filled.”Days later, the same recruiter sent him to the wrong address, which made him show up late to the actual meeting, to then find out… the role the client was speaking about was completely different from what the candidate was looking for. Let me be clear: This isn’t how recruitment should be done.We are here to represent both candidates and clients.We should be communicating clearly, confirming meetings, and aligning expectations.We should not be sending people out blindly.Candidates deserve respect. Clients deserve professionalism.To every candidate out there: please know NOT ALL recruiters operate this way. And to those of us in the industry: do better.



…more

Why Recruiters Don't Call Back.Ever sent your resume into the recruitment void, only to hear...nothing? That silence isn't just frustrating - it's mystifying.Here's the inside story.1. We forgetPicture this: A recruiter scanning hundreds of profiles, juggling phone calls with candidates, updating clients, rushing to meetings, and trying to document everything at once. Some days, our follow-up messages get buried under an avalanche of tasks. Not an excuse, but the honest reality of our chaotic days.2. We have no news"Any news on my application?" you ask. Sometimes we wonder the same thing! Many clients go silent for weeks, leaving us empty-handed when you reach out. We wish we had updates to share.3. We can't fit you at the momentIf you're not a fit for current roles, you join our "future talent" database. We work to fill specific client needs - they're the ones paying our bills. But when something perfect crosses our desk? You'll be our first call.4. We can't figure you outThose unexplained gaps in your resume? The 5 jobs in 3 years? That vague description of what you actually do? These things make us hesitate. Part of our job is spotting potential red flags before our clients do.5. We struggle with uncomfortable truthsSometimes, the feedback is awkward to deliver. A client might pass on you because of something said in an informal reference check or how you presented yourself (read: personal appearance). These conversations are difficult to navigate without someone getting hurt.We genuinely feel bad when communications drop. You deserve better, and the good recruiters know it.What's been your experience with recruitment communication? Has silence left you questioning your candidacy?hashtag#recruitment hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#positivelinksasia

Traditional recruitment often heavily emphasises past job titles, years of experience, and specific skills listed on resumes. I've noticed that focusing too much on the past can sometimes limit our view of a candidate's true potential. After all, we are recruiting for the future! ➡️ I believe that a growth mindset, a positive attitude, and a passion for learning are just as valuable. While some roles do have very specific requirements and previous experience is necessary, other roles can and should be more open to non-traditional backgrounds with transferable skills.Although, Gemini's picture suggestion for this post highlights that sometimes past experience is extremely crucial. For example, I wouldn’t go rock climbing with just a harness and no rope! 😂 I hope she has a can-do attitude..Happy Friday!

Salaries here are quite good, plus a 10% 401(k) contribution, 7 weeks of PTO, and excellent health/medical/dental coverage. The hashtag#TodayShow this morning had a segment about hashtag#ghosting. It focused on why job seekers don't hear back from hashtag#employers after hashtag#interviews. So often times, you're left hanging as to what's going on, which really frustrates those seeking employment! The same thing applies when applying for work. One thing that was left out, yet is a big reason for why this happens, is this. The hashtag#GreatRecession led many hashtag#companies to reduce HR departments to basically skeleton crews. A radical change from human resource departments being immune from hashtag#jobcuts! So with this reduction in HR staff, there's been an increase in job seekers being left hanging rather than getting responses. Thus, hashtag#businesses focused more on HR departments as hashtag#costcenters rather than being hashtag#profitcenters. And to save hashtag#money, they gutted human resources! Something that pretty much remains to this day as the departments continue to be "lean and mean." So responding to job hunters, unless they're being advanced to the next round or being given a hashtag#joboffer, is extremely low on the priority list. Does this stink from a job seeker's perspective? 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗯𝗲𝘁! And we literally have  two hashtag#generations who don't remember the days when you had received an acknowledgement of applying and being rejected. Thus hashtag#millenials and hashtag#genz have basically grown up with being left hanging! hashtag#jobapplicant hashtag#jobcandidate hashtag#jobcandidates hashtag#jobapplicants hashtag#candidate hashtag#applicant hashtag#applicants hashtag#candidates hashtag#job hashtag#jobs hashtag#newhire hashtag#newhires hashtag#recruiter hashtag#hiringmanger hashtag#employer hashtag#employers hashtag#recruiters hashtag#hiringmangers hashtag#jobinterview hashtag#jobinterviews hashtag#interview hashtag#interviews hashtag#interview hashtag#interviewing hashtag#interviewprep hashtag#interviewpreparation hashtag#interviewquestions hashtag#interviewtip hashtag#interviewtips hashtag#interviewexperience hashtag#interviewprocess hashtag#decision hashtag#decisions hashtag#hiring hashtag#hiringdecisions hashtag#applyingforajob hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#jobhunt hashtag#jobhunting hashtag#employment hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruiting hashtag#employability hashtag#recruitment hashtag#jobseeking hashtag#jobseeker hashtag#careeradvise hashtag#careeradvice hashtag#careeradvising hashtag#careercoaching hashtag#careercounseling hashtag#careerguidance hashtag#success hashtag#tips hashtag#questions hashtag#questionanswering hashtag#humanresources hashtag#HR hashtag#ronauerbach hashtag#ronauerbachmba Ron Auerbach, MBA hashtag#ARCSeattle

Username: Jose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCPJose Dominguez, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
Post Content:
Want to Recruit Like the Marine Corps? Here’s How. Public sector recruiting often feels like a reactive process—post and pray. The Marine Corps does it differently, and local and state governments can learn a lot from their playbook according to Work for America, a nonprofit initiative tackling the government staffing crisis in communities nationwide. 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗽:✅ 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗼𝗿𝗶𝘁𝘆. The Marines assign top talent to recruiting duty and give them leadership support. Government agencies must do the same—recruiting isn’t just HR’s side job; it’s a mission-critical function.✅ 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗿𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁. Even if you can’t match military resources, dedicating staff, budget, and 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲.✅ 𝗕𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲, not reactive. Build talent pipelines, nurture relationships, and engage prospects before openings arise.✅ 𝗖𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲𝗱, 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀. Recruitment success isn’t luck—it’s strategy, training, and execution.✅ 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲. Public sector jobs offer stability, impact, and career growth—highlight what makes your agency stand out.The Marine Corps doesn’t wait for recruits to show up. Why should your agency?What’s one recruitment strategy that’s worked for your agency? Drop it in the comments! 👇

When hiring, it’s easy to focus on what’s missing - the “must-haves” that aren’t quite there. But what if we flipped the lens? What if we focused on what a candidate brings, rather than what they don’t? 🤔 This week, we kicked off hiring for 13 brand-new roles in a fresh division for one of our leading clients. They didn’t just want to find people - they wanted to build a strong, capable team. And because they trusted the process, we moved quickly, engaged top talent, and secured the right candidates without unnecessary roadblocks.The best hiring processes are:👉 Simple & effective - No endless interviews, just smart, focused decision-making.👉 Candidate-first - Respect their time, and they’ll respect your role.👉 Built on trust - When clients trust the process, they attract top talent faster.At the end of the day, hiring is about finding the right people. If we always focus on what’s there instead of what’s missing, we open the door to incredible talent.hashtag#weploystories hashtag#hiring hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruitmentstories hashtag#smarthiring hashtag#talentacquisitiontips
